For additional information, please see .

c:property.name: extensionPoints
c:property.c:documentation: The extension points object contains style definitions for the marks of the panel.

c:complexType.name: AnyContinuousCartesianAxisExtensionPoints
c:complexType.c:documentation:
The extension points of the cartesian axis panel for continuous scale types.
Axes extension points can also be specified directly at the chart options level.
To use an extension point you must find its full name, by joining:
panel property name (ex: xAxis)
extension property (ex: zeroLine)
the "_" character
extension sub-property (ex: lineWidth)
and obtaining, for the examples, the camel-cased name: xAxisZeroLine_lineWidth (see ).

c:facetType.name: ContinuousCartesianAxisFacet
c:facetType.c:documentation: The options documentation class of the cartesian axis panel for continuous scale types (numeric or timeSeries).

c:property.name: domainRoundMode
c:property.c:documentation: The axis' domain rounding mode (applies to continuous axes).

c:property.name: desiredTickCount
c:property.c:documentation:
The desired number of major ticks.
A positive integer, possibly infinite.
Attention: This option is ignored when is specified!
Depending on the domain values extent, the labels' font size, the available space, the axis' orientation, and the minimum label spacing (given by ), a maximum number of ticks is implied.
The value of desiredTickCount is clamped to this layout imposed maximum.
When specified and finite, the tick calculation algorithm chooses, amongst possible tick units, the one that results in a number of ticks that is closest to the specified desired value.
When specified and infinite (Infinity), the layout imposed maximum is used instead.
The minimum tick count
This actually depends on the value of .
domainRoundMode is
For tick counts greater than two or three, the algorithm strives to satisfy the user's desire!
However, the algorithm always generates at least two or three ticks, ignoring both desiredTickCount and labelSpacingMin, if needed.
At least three ticks are generated for numeric domains having both negative and positive data. There are also temporal domain cases where a minimum of three ticks are generated.
When the labels of these ticks really overlap, one of the labels is kept visible and the other(s) is hidden.
This behavior ensures that, unless it is really impossible to do so, the axis serves one of its main purposes - allowing to translate visual lengths.
When three tick labels overlap, the middle label is kept visible and the end labels are hidden.
When two tick labels overlap, one of the labels — the one with tick value 0, if any, or the first one, if none — is kept visible and the other is hidden.
domainRoundMode is or
The algorithm always generates at least one tick.
Specifying a value of 1 results in the minimum possible tick count.
Domain type specifics
Numeric
When unspecified, the default value is Infinity.
Temporal
The value must be less than or equal to 10.
When unspecified, the default value is 5.
See for more information.

c:property.name: tickUnit
c:property.c:documentation:
The ticks' major unit (difference in domain value between consecutive ticks).
When a number, it must be a non-negative, finite, integer.
Numeric axis
Specified values are rounded down to one of the standard precisions: a number that is an integer power of 10, multiplied by 1, 2 or 5 (e.g. 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 50, ...).
Temporal axis
When a number or numeric string is specified, it is a the number of milliseconds of a duration.
It is rounded down to an integer and used directly. By default, the corresponding tick format will be the one of the greatest standard unit that is below the specified value.
When a (non-numeric) string is specified, it should be the code of a standard precision, optionally immediately preceded by an integer multiple (e.g. '25d' means twenty five days).
The standard time precision codes are defined in
This option should be used instead of the now deprecated
extension point, via and then scale.
Relations with other options
When both and are specified, and the former is greater than or equal to the later, then it is as if tickUnit had been specified with the value of tickUnitMin.
When both tickUnit and are specified, and tickUnit is less than tickUnitMin, then the value of tickUnitMin is used instead.
When both tickUnit and are specified, and tickUnit is greater than tickUnitMax, then the value of tickUnitMax is used instead.
When specified or implied, both and labelSpacingMin are ignored.
See related axis options: , , , and .
For numeric axes, see also and .

c:property.name: tickUnitMin
c:property.c:documentation:
The minimum ticks' major unit (difference in domain value between consecutive ticks).
Use this option to ensure that ticks are separated by a minimum value. For example, a value of 1 ensures ticks are integers, and of 'd', that hour ticks are not used.
When a number, it must be a non-negative finite integer.
The same value parsing rules of apply to this option, with the exception that rounding to a standard precision is performed up.
For numeric axes, the value of this option is combined with that of , resulting in the most restrictive one being used.
See for more information.

c:property.name: tickUnitMax
c:property.c:documentation:
The maximum ticks' major unit (difference in domain value between consecutive ticks).
Use this option to ensure that ticks are separated by at most a certain value. For example, a value of 100 ensures that the unit 200 will not be used, and of '3m' that a year or semester unit will not be used.
As another example, to ensure that the tick unit is less than 1000, either specify a tickUnitMax of 900, or, maybe better, specify a of 2.
When a number, it must be a positive integer.
The same value parsing rules of apply to this option.
For numeric axes, the value of this option is combined with that of , resulting in the most restrictive one being used.
See for more information.

c:property.name: fixedMin
c:property.c:documentation:
The fixed minimum domain value that the axis will show (applies to continuous axes).
The value is converted using the of the first dimension of the first role bound to the axis.
For example, if the base axis shows the category dimension, and the dimension is configured as type Date, and it uses the default converter, then it accepts:
values of type number, representing milliseconds as returned by the JavaScript's Date.getTime() method
values of type Date, which are accepted as is
values of type string, in a format defined by the dimension's .
The value may be bigger or smaller than the actual minimum value of the data.
When this property is specified, and is set to auto, clipping is activated in the plot panel. Elements that are drawn beyond its area are clipped.
When this property is specified together with fixedLength, fixedMax is ignored.
This property takes precedence over the property originIsZero.
See related axis options: , ,

c:property.name: fixedMax
c:property.c:documentation:
The fixed maximum domain value that the axis will show (applies to continuous axes).
The value is converted using the of the first dimension of the first role bound to the axis.
For example, if the base axis shows the category dimension, and the dimension is configured as type Date, and it uses the default converter, then it accepts:
values of type number, representing milliseconds as returned by the JavaScript's Date.getTime() method
values of type Date, which are accepted as is
values of type string, in a format defined by the dimension's .
The value may be bigger or smaller than the actual maximum value of the data.
When this property is specified, and is set to auto, clipping is activated in the plot panel. Elements that are drawn beyond its area are clipped.
This property takes precedence over the property originIsZero.
This property is ignored if fixedMin and fixedLength are both specified.
Constraints behavior
If fixedMin and fixedLength are specified but fixedMax is not, a fixed maximum is implied from the max and length values
If fixedMax and fixedLength are specified but fixedMin is not, a fixed minimum is implied from the max and length values
If fixedMin and fixedMax specified, but fixedLength is not, the fixed maximum and minimum are set directly
If all are specified: fixedMax is ignored and the behavior falls to the first case.
See related axis options: , ,

c:property.name: fixedLength
c:property.c:documentation:
The fixed length of the domain that the axis will show (applies to numeric axes).
A string value is converted to a number.
The value may be bigger or smaller than the actual length of the data.
This property takes precedence over the property originIsZero.
If fixedMin is specified, they take precedence over fixedMax.
Domain type specifics
Temporal A time interval of type is transformed to its equivalent in milliseconds. This value will be used directly.
Numeric The value is used directly.
See related axis options: , ,

c:property.name: originIsZero
c:property.c:documentation:
Indicates if it should be ensured that the 0 domain value is shown (applies to continuous axes).
The properties fixedMin and fixedMax have precedence over this one. If this property is true and respecting it would require changing the minimum value, but the option fixedMin is also specified, then this property is ignored. The same would apply if it were required to change the maximum value, but the property fixedMax was also specified.

c:property.name: ratio
c:property.c:documentation: The ratio value that defines the proportion between a domain interval and a range interval.

c:property.name: ratioAlign
c:property.c:documentation:
The type of alignment to use when Ratio is defined.
The possible values are:
'right'': the maximum is kept; if necessary, values to the left are clipped and remain hidden in the visualization
'left': the minimum is kept; if necessary, values to the left are clipped and remain hidden in the visualization
'top': same as 'right'
'bottom': same as 'left'
'center': neither maximum or minimum are kept; if necessary, values from both sides are clipped and remain hidden in the visualization

c:property.name: preserveRatio
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if the initial ratio between domain and range should be preserved between renders.

c:property.name: domainScope
c:property.c:documentation:
Controls the type of scale domain coordination that should be performed amongst the axes of the same id of each small chart (applies to continuous axes).
The value can only be specified if the axis has vertical orientation. Conversely, the value can only be specified if the axis has horizontal orientation.

c:property.name: minorTicks
c:property.c:documentation: Indicates if minor ticks are shown between major ticks (applies to continuous axes).

c:property.name: minorTicks
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of a minor tick rule mark (applies to continuous axes).

c:property.name: scale
c:property.c:documentation: The extension point of the axis' scale object (applies to continuous axes).
